exampleSentence: Bonjour Madame, comment allez-vous aujourd'hui?
exampleTranslation: Hello Madam, how are you today?
contextNotes: The standard, polite greeting used from morning until evening. Always use 'Bonjour' when entering a shop or starting a conversation.

exampleSentence: Salut! On se voit plus tard.
exampleTranslation: Hi! We'll see each other later.
contextNotes: Informal greeting, typically used with friends, family, or people you know well. Can be used for both 'hello' and 'goodbye'.

exampleSentence: Au revoir, Monsieur. Bonne journée!
exampleTranslation: Goodbye, Sir. Have a good day!
contextNotes: The standard, polite way to say goodbye. The literal translation is closer to 'Until we see each other again'.

exampleSentence: Bonjour Paul, comment ça va ce matin?
exampleTranslation: Hello Paul, how are you this morning?
contextNotes: The most common informal way to ask 'How are you?' The standard response is usually 'Ça va bien, merci' (I'm fine, thanks).

exampleSentence: Merci beaucoup pour votre aide.
exampleTranslation: Thank you very much for your help.
contextNotes: Essential word for politeness. 'Merci beaucoup' means 'Thank you very much'.

exampleSentence: — Merci pour le café. — De rien.
exampleTranslation: — Thanks for the coffee. — You're welcome.
contextNotes: A casual and common response to 'Merci'. More formal options include 'Je vous en prie' (formal) or 'Il n'y a pas de quoi'.

exampleSentence: Puis-je avoir l'addition, s'il vous plaît?
exampleTranslation: May I have the bill, please?
contextNotes: Crucial for politeness. Use 'S'il vous plaît' when addressing strangers, elders, or in a professional setting (using 'vous').

exampleSentence: Pardon, je n'ai pas compris ce que vous avez dit.
exampleTranslation: Excuse me, I didn't understand what you said.
contextNotes: Used to apologize for a minor offense, to ask someone to repeat something, or to get someone's attention (like 'Excuse me' in English).

exampleSentence: Bonsoir à tous! J'espère que vous allez bien.
exampleTranslation: Good evening everyone! I hope you are well.
contextNotes: Used when greeting someone in the late afternoon or evening (generally after 5 or 6 PM). Also used when leaving a place in the evening.

exampleSentence: Je m'appelle Sophie, enchantée de faire votre connaissance.
exampleTranslation: My name is Sophie, pleased to make your acquaintance.
contextNotes: A polite and common response when introduced to someone new. If the speaker is female, the spelling is 'enchantée'.

exampleSentence: Je dois partir maintenant, à bientôt!
exampleTranslation: I have to leave now, see you soon!
contextNotes: A friendly way to say goodbye when you expect to see the person again relatively soon.

exampleSentence: Bonjour Professeur, comment vous portez-vous ce matin?
exampleTranslation: Hello Professor, how are you this morning?
contextNotes: A very formal and respectful way to ask about someone's well-being, using the verb 'se porter'. Less common than 'Comment allez-vous?' but highly polite.

exampleSentence: Quelle surprise! Ravi de vous revoir après toutes ces années.
exampleTranslation: What a surprise! Delighted to see you again after all these years.
contextNotes: Used specifically when greeting someone you haven't seen in a while. Requires agreement (masculine 'ravi', feminine 'ravie').

exampleSentence: Je vous remercie pour votre aide, passez une excellente journée.
exampleTranslation: Thank you for your help, have an excellent day.
contextNotes: A very polite and slightly formal way to end an interaction, elevating the standard 'Bonne journée' (Have a good day).

exampleSentence: Veuillez agréer, Madame la Directrice, mes salutations distinguées.
exampleTranslation: Please accept, Madam Director, my distinguished greetings (formal closing).
contextNotes: Extremely formal, rarely used in spoken conversation. This phrase is typically reserved for written correspondence (emails or letters) to high-ranking officials or professionals.

exampleSentence: J'ai un chat et une chienne.
exampleTranslation: I have one cat (masc.) and one dog (fem.).
contextNotes: Also acts as the indefinite article 'a' or 'an'. It must agree in gender: 'un' (masc.) or 'une' (fem.).

exampleSentence: Il est deux heures de l'après-midi.
exampleTranslation: It is two o'clock in the afternoon.
contextNotes: The 'x' is silent unless followed by a vowel or silent 'h' (liaison), where it sounds like a 'z' (e.g., 'deux ans' -> 'deu-z-ans').

exampleSentence: Nous avons trois enfants.
exampleTranslation: We have three children.
contextNotes: A very common number. The 's' is silent.

exampleSentence: Mon anniversaire est le dix mai.
exampleTranslation: My birthday is May tenth.
contextNotes: The 'x' is usually pronounced like an 's' at the end of the word, but silent when used before a noun (e.g., 'dix livres').

exampleSentence: Elle a vingt ans.
exampleTranslation: She is twenty years old.
contextNotes: The 'g' and 't' are silent. This number forms the basis for counting 80 (quatre-vingts) in French.

exampleSentence: Ce livre coûte cent euros.
exampleTranslation: This book costs one hundred euros.
contextNotes: The 't' is usually silent. It takes an 's' (cents) only when multiplied and not followed by another number (e.g., 'deux cents', but 'deux cent un').

exampleSentence: La ville a plus de mille habitants.
exampleTranslation: The city has more than one thousand inhabitants.
contextNotes: Unlike English, French does not use a comma for thousands; it uses a space (e.g., 1 000). 'Mille' never takes an 's'.

exampleSentence: Quel est votre numéro de téléphone?
exampleTranslation: What is your phone number?
contextNotes: Refers to the mathematical concept or a specific quantity. Note the difference: 'le nombre' (number) vs. 'le numéro' (identification number/digit).

exampleSentence: C'est la première fois que je viens ici.
exampleTranslation: This is the first time I have come here.
contextNotes: Ordinal numbers indicate rank. This is the only ordinal that changes form significantly for gender (masc./fem.).

exampleSentence: J'ai mangé la moitié du gâteau.
exampleTranslation: I ate half of the cake.
contextNotes: Used frequently in daily conversation for division or sharing. It is always feminine.

exampleSentence: Le chiffre d'affaires a augmenté de 10% cette année.
exampleTranslation: The turnover increased by 10% this year.
contextNotes: A key business and economic term. Literally means 'figure of business'. Often abbreviated as CA.

exampleSentence: Choisissez un nombre impair entre un et dix.
exampleTranslation: Choose an odd number between one and ten.
contextNotes: The opposite is 'pair' (even). Used frequently in games, math, and logistics.

exampleSentence: Arrondissez le résultat à deux décimales.
exampleTranslation: Round the result to two decimal places.
contextNotes: In French (and most of Europe), the decimal point is represented by a comma (e.g., 3,14 instead of 3.14).

exampleSentence: Nous devons trouver un dénominateur commun pour résoudre ce conflit.
exampleTranslation: We must find a common denominator to resolve this conflict.
contextNotes: Used both mathematically and figuratively to mean a shared characteristic or basis for agreement.

exampleSentence: Essayer de satisfaire tout le monde, c'est la quadrature du cercle.
exampleTranslation: Trying to satisfy everyone is squaring the circle (an impossible task).
contextNotes: Refers to a famous unsolved geometric problem from antiquity, now used idiomatically to describe something extremely difficult or impossible to achieve.

exampleSentence: Quelle est votre couleur préférée ?
exampleTranslation: What is your favorite color?
contextNotes: In French, 'couleur' is always feminine (une couleur). Remember to make adjectives agree in gender and number when describing colors.

exampleSentence: J'ai acheté une voiture rouge.
exampleTranslation: I bought a red car.
contextNotes: Most color adjectives, including 'rouge', are placed after the noun they modify. 'Rouge' does not change form for feminine nouns (it's invariant).

exampleSentence: Le ciel est d'un bleu magnifique aujourd'hui.
exampleTranslation: The sky is a magnificent blue today.
contextNotes: The feminine form is 'bleue'. Note the common expression 'avoir le blues' (to have the blues/to feel down), borrowed from English.

exampleSentence: Nous devons respecter les espaces verts de la ville.
exampleTranslation: We must respect the green spaces of the city.
contextNotes: The feminine form is 'verte'. 'Être vert de jalousie' means 'to be green with envy'.

exampleSentence: Attention, le feu est jaune !
exampleTranslation: Watch out, the light is yellow!
contextNotes: Like 'rouge', 'jaune' is invariant in the feminine form (it doesn't change spelling).

exampleSentence: Elle porte une robe blanche pour la cérémonie.
exampleTranslation: She is wearing a white dress for the ceremony.
contextNotes: This color has an irregular feminine form: 'blanche'. 'Nuit blanche' means an all-nighter or sleepless night.

exampleSentence: Il fait nuit noire dehors.
exampleTranslation: It is pitch black outside.
contextNotes: The feminine form is 'noire'. 'Le marché noir' means 'the black market'.

exampleSentence: Le ciel est gris et il va pleuvoir.
exampleTranslation: The sky is grey and it is going to rain.
contextNotes: The feminine form is 'grise'. Note that the masculine plural is also 'gris' (no change).

exampleSentence: J'ai des chaussures marron.
exampleTranslation: I have brown shoes.
contextNotes: Colors derived from nouns (like fruits, flowers, or stones) are generally invariable, meaning 'marron' never takes an 'e' or 's'.

exampleSentence: J'aime beaucoup cette nouvelle teinte de vert.
exampleTranslation: I really like this new shade of green.
contextNotes: Used when discussing subtle variations within a color family. Often paired with adjectives like 'claire' (light) or 'foncée' (dark).

exampleSentence: Les plumes du paon sont magnifiquement chatoyantes.
exampleTranslation: The peacock's feathers are magnificently shimmering.
contextNotes: A descriptive adjective used for materials that change color or shine depending on the light, such as silk, certain minerals, or oil slicks.

exampleSentence: Elle a décoré la chambre avec des couleurs pastel.
exampleTranslation: She decorated the room with pastel colors.
contextNotes: When used as an adjective describing a color (like 'des bleus pastel'), it is invariable (does not take an 's' or 'e').

exampleSentence: Il préfère les couleurs vives comme le fuchsia.
exampleTranslation: He prefers bright colors like fuchsia.
contextNotes: This adjective means 'lively' or 'vivid'. The feminine form is 'vive'. It is essential for describing intensity of color.

exampleSentence: L'étude de la perception chromatique est complexe.
exampleTranslation: The study of chromatic perception is complex.
contextNotes: A technical term, often used in art, physics, or biology, referring to color, especially in relation to the spectrum or the visual system.

exampleSentence: Le ciel au coucher du soleil prenait une teinte incarnate.
exampleTranslation: The sky at sunset was taking on a deep crimson hue.
contextNotes: A literary or specialized color term, rarely used in everyday conversation. It refers to a specific, intense shade of red, often associated with flesh or blood.

exampleSentence: Que faisons-nous aujourd'hui ?
exampleTranslation: What are we doing today?
contextNotes: A contraction of 'au jour d'hui' (on the day of now). It is one of the most essential time adverbs.

exampleSentence: Je te verrai demain matin.
exampleTranslation: I will see you tomorrow morning.
contextNotes: Used frequently. Note the nasal 'anh' sound at the end. 'Après-demain' means 'the day after tomorrow'.

exampleSentence: Il a plu toute la journée hier.
exampleTranslation: It rained all day yesterday.
contextNotes: 'Avant-hier' means 'the day before yesterday'. It is often placed at the beginning or end of a sentence.

exampleSentence: Quelle heure est-il ?
exampleTranslation: What time is it?
contextNotes: Always feminine. Used to ask or tell the time. Note the difference: 'le temps' is used for weather or duration, 'l'heure' for clock time.

exampleSentence: Nous partons en vacances la semaine prochaine.
exampleTranslation: We are leaving for vacation next week.
contextNotes: French weeks start on Monday (lundi) and end on Sunday (dimanche).

exampleSentence: J'ai un examen à la fin du mois.
exampleTranslation: I have an exam at the end of the month.
contextNotes: The 's' is silent. Months are not capitalized in French unless they start a sentence.

exampleSentence: J'ai passé une très bonne année.
exampleTranslation: I had a very good year.
contextNotes: Feminine noun for the year as a duration or period (e.g., 'toute l'année'). Contrast with 'le an' (masculine, used for counting, e.g., 'dix ans').

exampleSentence: Nous vivons au vingt-et-unième siècle.
exampleTranslation: We live in the twenty-first century.
contextNotes: Used to refer to historical periods. Note that French uses ordinal numbers (premier, deuxième, etc.) for centuries.

exampleSentence: Vérifie la date sur le calendrier.
exampleTranslation: Check the date on the calendar.
contextNotes: A standard term for the object used to track dates. The French word for 'date' is 'la date'.

exampleSentence: Il est toujours très ponctuel pour les réunions.
exampleTranslation: He is always very punctual for meetings.
contextNotes: A useful adjective when discussing timeliness. It agrees in gender: 'ponctuel' (masc.), 'ponctuelle' (fem.).

exampleSentence: Nous devons respecter le délai de livraison.
exampleTranslation: We must respect the delivery deadline.
contextNotes: Crucial business and administrative term. Often used with verbs like 'respecter' (to respect/meet) or 'dépasser' (to exceed).

exampleSentence: La beauté de ces fleurs est malheureusement éphémère.
exampleTranslation: The beauty of these flowers is unfortunately ephemeral.
contextNotes: A more literary or sophisticated term used to describe things that last for a very short time. It is invariable in gender.

exampleSentence: Les années 80 étaient une décennie marquante.
exampleTranslation: The 80s were a significant decade.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to a period of ten years. Less common in daily speech than 'année' or 'siècle'.

exampleSentence: Le magasin ferme à minuit pile.
exampleTranslation: The store closes exactly at midnight.
contextNotes: Used without an article when stating the time ('Il est minuit'). 'Midi' means noon.

exampleSentence: Quelle est la durée du film ?
exampleTranslation: What is the duration of the movie?
contextNotes: Essential word for asking how long something lasts. Derived from the verb 'durer' (to last).

exampleSentence: J'achète une baguette de pain tous les matins.
exampleTranslation: I buy a baguette of bread every morning.
contextNotes: Bread (especially the baguette) is central to French meals. It is often placed directly on the table, not on a plate.

exampleSentence: Il faut boire beaucoup d'eau quand il fait chaud.
exampleTranslation: You must drink a lot of water when it is hot.
contextNotes: A common irregular verb. Note the difference between 'boire' (to drink) and 'manger' (to eat).

exampleSentence: Je prends un café après le déjeuner.
exampleTranslation: I have a coffee after lunch.
contextNotes: In France, ordering 'un café' usually means a small, strong espresso. If you want filter coffee, you might ask for 'un café filtre'.

exampleSentence: Nous avons du fromage et du vin pour le dessert.
exampleTranslation: We have cheese and wine for dessert.
contextNotes: Cheese is typically eaten after the main course and before dessert (or sometimes replacing dessert), not usually before the meal.

exampleSentence: Qu'est-ce que tu aimes manger pour le dîner ?
exampleTranslation: What do you like to eat for dinner?
contextNotes: A regular -ER verb. Used broadly for consuming food.

exampleSentence: Le plat principal était du bœuf bourguignon.
exampleTranslation: The main course was beef bourguignon.
contextNotes: Often abbreviated simply as 'le plat'. In formal dining, it follows 'l'entrée' (appetizer).

exampleSentence: Passe-moi la fourchette, s'il te plaît.
exampleTranslation: Pass me the fork, please.
contextNotes: Essential vocabulary for setting the table ('mettre la table').

exampleSentence: J'adore acheter des légumes frais au marché.
exampleTranslation: I love buying fresh vegetables at the market.
contextNotes: Open-air markets are crucial for buying high-quality, seasonal produce directly from vendors in France.

exampleSentence: Ce gâteau est absolument délicieux !
exampleTranslation: This cake is absolutely delicious!
contextNotes: The feminine form is 'délicieuse'. A very common compliment in French dining.

exampleSentence: Nous avons participé à une dégustation de vins de Bordeaux.
exampleTranslation: We participated in a Bordeaux wine tasting.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to the act of sampling food or drink carefully, often used in the context of wine, cheese, or regional specialties.

exampleSentence: N'oubliez pas d'assaisonner la viande avec du sel et du poivre.
exampleTranslation: Don't forget to season the meat with salt and pepper.
contextNotes: A key verb in cooking. The noun form is 'l'assaisonnement' (seasoning).

translation: local soil/region; sense of place (in food/wine)
exampleSentence: Ce vin exprime parfaitement le terroir de la Bourgogne.
exampleTranslation: This wine perfectly expresses the sense of place of Burgundy.
contextNotes: A powerful concept in French gastronomy, referring to the complete natural environment (soil, climate, tradition) that affects the quality and unique character of a food product, especially wine and cheese.

exampleSentence: J'apprécie l'amertume subtile du chocolat noir.
exampleTranslation: I appreciate the subtle bitterness of dark chocolate.
contextNotes: One of the four basic tastes ('les saveurs'). Useful for describing complex flavors in coffee, beer, or dark chocolate.

exampleSentence: Il faut laisser mijoter cette sauce pendant au moins deux heures.
exampleTranslation: You must let this sauce simmer slowly for at least two hours.
contextNotes: Refers to slow, gentle cooking, essential for traditional French dishes like stews (pot-au-feu, daube). It implies patience and flavor development.

exampleSentence: En France, l'art de la table est une tradition respectée, allant du dressage des couverts aux accords mets et vins.
exampleTranslation: In France, the art of dining is a respected tradition, ranging from the placement of cutlery to food and wine pairings.
contextNotes: This phrase encompasses the entire culture surrounding eating: presentation, etiquette, quality of tableware, and the social ritual of the meal itself.

exampleSentence: J'ai acheté une pomme rouge au marché.
exampleTranslation: I bought a red apple at the market.
contextNotes: A very common fruit. Used widely in French cuisine (e.g., Tarte Tatin). 'Pomme de terre' means potato.

exampleSentence: Les lapins aiment manger des carottes crues.
exampleTranslation: Rabbits like to eat raw carrots.
contextNotes: A fundamental vegetable. Often served cooked, but 'crudités' (raw vegetables) are popular as appetizers.

exampleSentence: Tu veux une banane pour ton goûter ?
exampleTranslation: Do you want a banana for your snack?
contextNotes: Despite being an imported fruit, it is extremely common and widely available in France.

exampleSentence: Nous avons cueilli du raisin dans le vignoble.
exampleTranslation: We picked grapes in the vineyard.
contextNotes: Essential word due to France's wine culture. 'Un grain de raisin' refers to a single grape.

exampleSentence: J'ai besoin de tomates pour faire la sauce.
exampleTranslation: I need tomatoes to make the sauce.
contextNotes: Used extensively in Mediterranean and Provençal cooking. Often considered a vegetable in culinary use, though botanically a fruit.

exampleSentence: Ajoutez un peu d'oignon haché à la soupe.
exampleTranslation: Add a little chopped onion to the soup.
contextNotes: A cooking staple. The famous 'soupe à l'oignon' (onion soup) is a classic French dish.

exampleSentence: Les fraises de saison sont délicieuses.
exampleTranslation: Seasonal strawberries are delicious.
contextNotes: A beloved spring/summer fruit. Often served simply with a little sugar or cream (crème fraîche).

exampleSentence: Il faut manger plus de légumes verts pour être en forme.
exampleTranslation: You must eat more green vegetables to be healthy.
contextNotes: The general term for vegetables. Often used in the plural: 'les légumes'.

exampleSentence: Quel est ton fruit préféré ?
exampleTranslation: What is your favorite fruit?
contextNotes: The general term for fruit. Often served as dessert (le dessert) or as a snack (le goûter).

exampleSentence: La ratatouille contient des aubergines et des courgettes.
exampleTranslation: Ratatouille contains eggplant and zucchini.
contextNotes: Crucial for Mediterranean dishes like Ratatouille. Note the feminine gender.

exampleSentence: Nous avons fait une soupe de courgettes très crémeuse.
exampleTranslation: We made a very creamy zucchini soup.
contextNotes: Very common summer squash in France. Often used in soups, gratins, and ratatouille.

exampleSentence: Les abricots du Roussillon sont très sucrés.
exampleTranslation: Apricots from Roussillon are very sweet.
contextNotes: A popular stone fruit, especially in the south of France. Often used in jams and tarts.

exampleSentence: Cette année, la récolte de cerises a été exceptionnelle.
exampleTranslation: This year, the cherry harvest was exceptional.
contextNotes: Useful term when discussing seasonal produce, farming, or wine production (vendanges is specific to grapes).

exampleSentence: Mon grand-père passe ses journées à travailler dans son potager.
exampleTranslation: My grandfather spends his days working in his vegetable garden.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to the garden dedicated to growing vegetables and herbs, distinct from a flower garden (jardin).

exampleSentence: Nous achetons toujours nos légumes directement chez le maraîcher local.
exampleTranslation: We always buy our vegetables directly from the local market gardener.
contextNotes: Specific term for a farmer who grows and sells vegetables, often directly at markets (marchés). Implies high quality and local sourcing.

exampleSentence: J'aime préparer le dîner dans ma nouvelle cuisine.
exampleTranslation: I like preparing dinner in my new kitchen.
contextNotes: This word can refer both to the physical room (the kitchen) and the style of cooking (e.g., la cuisine française - French cuisine).

exampleSentence: Quel est le plat du jour aujourd'hui ?
exampleTranslation: What is the dish of the day today?
contextNotes: Refers to a specific prepared food item (like a main course). It can also mean a plate, but 'assiette' is more common for the eating utensil.

exampleSentence: Il faut cuire le poulet pendant quarante minutes.
exampleTranslation: The chicken must be cooked for forty minutes.
contextNotes: A general verb for applying heat to food. Use 'faire cuire' (to make cook) or 'cuire' directly. Conjugates like 'dire'.

exampleSentence: Nous prenons trois repas par jour : le petit-déjeuner, le déjeuner et le dîner.
exampleTranslation: We have three meals a day: breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
contextNotes: Refers to the event of eating (breakfast, lunch, dinner). Do not confuse with 'le plat' (the specific food item).

exampleSentence: J'ai besoin de tous les ingrédients pour faire ce gâteau.
exampleTranslation: I need all the ingredients to make this cake.
contextNotes: Always used in the plural when referring to components of a recipe. The singular is 'un ingrédient'.

translation: to taste / to snack (noun: the afternoon snack)
exampleSentence: Tu devrais goûter cette sauce, elle est délicieuse.
exampleTranslation: You should taste this sauce, it is delicious.
contextNotes: As a noun, 'le goûter' is the traditional afternoon snack for children (around 4 PM), often consisting of bread and chocolate or pastries.

exampleSentence: Faites bouillir l'eau avant d'ajouter les pâtes.
exampleTranslation: Boil the water before adding the pasta.
contextNotes: The verb 'bouillir' means 'to boil,' but it is usually used with 'faire' (faire bouillir) to mean 'to bring something to a boil.'

exampleSentence: Ma grand-mère m'a donné sa recette secrète de tarte aux pommes.
exampleTranslation: My grandmother gave me her secret apple pie recipe.
contextNotes: Do not confuse with 'la réception' (the reception desk/party). This word specifically refers to cooking instructions.

exampleSentence: On va servir le dessert après le café.
exampleTranslation: We are going to serve dessert after coffee.
contextNotes: Also used reflexively ('se servir') meaning 'to help oneself' (e.g., Servez-vous! - Help yourself!).

exampleSentence: N'oubliez pas d'assaisonner la viande avec du sel et du poivre.
exampleTranslation: Don't forget to season the meat with salt and pepper.
contextNotes: This verb covers the addition of salt, pepper, herbs, and spices to enhance flavor. The noun is 'l'assaisonnement' (the seasoning).

exampleSentence: Laissez mijoter la sauce à feu doux pendant une heure.
exampleTranslation: Let the sauce simmer over low heat for an hour.
contextNotes: Implies slow cooking over low heat, often used for stews, sauces, or soups, resulting in tender, flavorful dishes. It evokes traditional French cooking methods.

translation: the garnish / the filling (for a pie/cake)
exampleSentence: La garniture de cette quiche est faite de légumes et de fromage.
exampleTranslation: The filling of this quiche is made of vegetables and cheese.
contextNotes: Highly versatile term. Can refer to decorative toppings (garnish) or the main substance inside a pastry, sandwich, or savory dish (filling/stuffing).

exampleSentence: Après avoir saisi la viande, il faut déglacer la poêle avec du vin blanc.
exampleTranslation: After searing the meat, you must deglaze the pan with white wine.
contextNotes: A fundamental technique in French sauce making, involving adding liquid (wine, stock, etc.) to a hot pan to dissolve the caramelized bits (sucres) left from searing meat.

exampleSentence: Pour réussir la mayonnaise, il faut créer une bonne émulsion entre l'huile et le jaune d'œuf.
exampleTranslation: To succeed with mayonnaise, you must create a good emulsion between the oil and the egg yolk.
contextNotes: A technical term referring to the stable mixture of two immiscible liquids (like oil and water/vinegar), crucial for sauces like hollandaise or vinaigrette.

exampleSentence: La France est fière de son riche patrimoine culinaire, reconnu mondialement.
exampleTranslation: France is proud of its rich culinary heritage, recognized worldwide.
contextNotes: This phrase refers to the historical traditions, techniques, and regional specialties that define a country's food culture, often used in formal or academic discussions about gastronomy.

exampleSentence: Passe-moi la chaise s'il te plaît, je suis fatigué.
exampleTranslation: Pass me the chair please, I am tired.
contextNotes: A fundamental vocabulary item. Always feminine: 'une chaise'. Used for any standard seating without arms.

exampleSentence: Nous dînons toujours à la table de la cuisine.
exampleTranslation: We always have dinner at the kitchen table.
contextNotes: Like 'chaise', this is a core piece of furniture. It is feminine, 'une table'.

exampleSentence: Mon chat dort sur le lit toute la journée.
exampleTranslation: My cat sleeps on the bed all day long.
contextNotes: Masculine ('un lit'). The phrase 'faire le lit' means 'to make the bed'.

exampleSentence: On a acheté un nouveau canapé pour le salon.
exampleTranslation: We bought a new sofa for the living room.
contextNotes: The most common term for a sofa. 'Un divan' is also used but less frequent.

exampleSentence: Range tes vêtements dans l'armoire.
exampleTranslation: Put away your clothes in the wardrobe.
contextNotes: Feminine ('une armoire'). This word refers to a large standing cupboard, often used for clothes (like a wardrobe or armoire in English).

exampleSentence: J'ai besoin d'un grand bureau pour travailler à la maison.
exampleTranslation: I need a large desk to work from home.
contextNotes: This word means both 'desk' and 'office' (the room or the company). Context is key to understanding which meaning is intended.

exampleSentence: Accroche le miroir au-dessus de la commode.
exampleTranslation: Hang the mirror above the chest of drawers.
contextNotes: Masculine ('un miroir'). Essential for bathroom and bedroom vocabulary.

exampleSentence: Les livres sont rangés sur l'étagère du salon.
exampleTranslation: The books are stored on the living room shelf.
contextNotes: Feminine ('une étagère'). Often used in the plural ('les étagères') to refer to a bookcase or set of shelves.

exampleSentence: Le chien a fait une tache sur le nouveau tapis.
exampleTranslation: The dog made a stain on the new rug.
contextNotes: Refers to a loose rug or a fitted carpet. Masculine ('un tapis').

exampleSentence: Je garde mes chaussettes dans le tiroir supérieur de la commode.
exampleTranslation: I keep my socks in the top drawer of the chest of drawers.
contextNotes: Feminine ('une commode'). Note the difference from 'l'armoire' (wardrobe). A 'tiroir' is a drawer.

exampleSentence: J'aime lire confortablement installé dans mon vieux fauteuil.
exampleTranslation: I like to read comfortably settled in my old armchair.
contextNotes: Masculine ('un fauteuil'). Distinct from 'la chaise' (chair) as it implies a padded, single seat with arms.

exampleSentence: Il y a une lampe et un livre sur mon chevet.
exampleTranslation: There is a lamp and a book on my bedside table.
contextNotes: Short for 'table de chevet'. It literally means 'at the head/pillow'. Often used alone as 'le chevet'.

exampleSentence: Nous utilisons des tabourets hauts pour le comptoir de la cuisine.
exampleTranslation: We use tall stools for the kitchen counter.
contextNotes: Masculine ('un tabouret'). Refers to a seat without a back or arms, often used in bars or kitchens.

exampleSentence: Ma grand-mère expose sa porcelaine ancienne dans le vaisselier du salon.
exampleTranslation: My grandmother displays her antique porcelain in the china cabinet in the living room.
contextNotes: Masculine ('un vaisselier'). This piece of furniture is specifically designed to store and display 'la vaisselle' (crockery/dishes). Often found in dining rooms.

exampleSentence: Le rembourrage du siège est usé et doit être remplacé.
exampleTranslation: The padding of the seat is worn and needs to be replaced.
contextNotes: Masculine ('un rembourrage'). A technical term related to the interior structure of soft furniture (canapés, fauteuils). Useful when discussing furniture restoration or quality.

exampleSentence: Ma mère cuisine très bien les crêpes.
exampleTranslation: My mother cooks crêpes very well.
contextNotes: One of the most fundamental family terms. Use 'maman' for the informal, affectionate term (mom/mommy).

exampleSentence: Mon père travaille dans l'informatique.
exampleTranslation: My father works in IT.
contextNotes: Use 'papa' for the informal, affectionate term (dad/daddy). Remember that 'père' can also mean 'priest' in a religious context.

exampleSentence: Mes parents vivent à la campagne.
exampleTranslation: My parents live in the countryside.
contextNotes: In French, even if the group includes both genders, the masculine plural form is used to refer to both mother and father.

exampleSentence: J'ai un grand frère qui est étudiant.
exampleTranslation: I have an older brother who is a student.
contextNotes: Used for a male sibling. The word 'frère' is also used in religious contexts to mean 'monk' or 'friar'.

exampleSentence: Ma sœur et moi, nous nous entendons bien.
exampleTranslation: My sister and I get along well.
contextNotes: Used for a female sibling. Note the 'œ' ligature, pronounced like the 'u' in 'fur'.

exampleSentence: Nous avons trois enfants : deux filles et un garçon.
exampleTranslation: We have three children: two girls and one boy.
contextNotes: This word can mean 'children' (plural) or 'child' (singular, common usage, e.g., 'un enfant'). It is always masculine plural when referring to a mixed group.

exampleSentence: Mon mari est rentré tard du travail.
exampleTranslation: My husband came home late from work.
contextNotes: The formal term for husband. 'Époux' is a more formal or administrative synonym.

exampleSentence: Sa femme est très gentille.
exampleTranslation: His wife is very kind.
contextNotes: This word means both 'woman' and 'wife,' depending on the context. If you want to specify 'my woman,' you must use 'ma femme'.

exampleSentence: J'aime beaucoup mes grands-parents.
exampleTranslation: I like my grandparents a lot (or: I love my grandparents).
contextNotes: When referring to people, 'aimer' usually means 'to love.' However, 'aimer beaucoup' often translates to 'to like a lot' or 'to be very fond of,' softening the intensity.

exampleSentence: Nous partageons les dépenses du foyer à parts égales.
exampleTranslation: We share the household expenses equally.
contextNotes: Refers less to the physical building (which is 'la maison') and more to the domestic unit, the center of family life, or the hearth.

exampleSentence: Il y a un lien très fort entre les cousins.
exampleTranslation: There is a very strong bond between the cousins.
contextNotes: Used metaphorically to describe emotional or familial connections. Also used literally for a physical link or a web link.

exampleSentence: Malgré leurs disputes, ils s'entendent bien au fond.
exampleTranslation: Despite their arguments, they fundamentally get along well.
contextNotes: Crucial verb for discussing relationship dynamics. It is always used with the reflexive pronoun (s'). The literal meaning is 'to hear oneself.'

exampleSentence: Nous passons Noël avec ma belle-famille cette année.
exampleTranslation: We are spending Christmas with my in-laws this year.
contextNotes: Literally 'beautiful family.' Used to refer to one's spouse's parents and siblings. 'Beau/belle' is used for all in-law relations (e.g., 'beau-père' for father-in-law).

exampleSentence: La filiation biologique n'est pas toujours le facteur déterminant.
exampleTranslation: Biological kinship is not always the determining factor.
contextNotes: A formal term, often used in legal, sociological, or historical contexts when discussing lineage or the establishment of parentage.

exampleSentence: Il est important de préserver l'héritage culturel familial.
exampleTranslation: It is important to preserve the family's cultural heritage.
contextNotes: Refers both to material goods passed down (inheritance) and non-material traditions, values, and history (heritage).

exampleSentence: Il est important de prendre soin de son corps.
exampleTranslation: It is important to take care of one's body.
contextNotes: A fundamental word. Used broadly for physical structure. 'Corps' is masculine.

exampleSentence: Comment va votre santé aujourd'hui ?
exampleTranslation: How is your health today?
contextNotes: Commonly used in greetings, e.g., 'À ta santé!' (To your health! - when toasting).

exampleSentence: J'ai mal à la tête depuis ce matin.
exampleTranslation: I have had a headache since this morning.
contextNotes: Always constructed with 'avoir' + 'mal' + 'à' + definite article + body part (e.g., 'J'ai mal au ventre').

exampleSentence: J'ai pris rendez-vous chez le médecin.
exampleTranslation: I made an appointment with the doctor.
contextNotes: The feminine form is 'la docteure' or sometimes 'la médecin'. 'Chez le médecin' means 'at the doctor's office'.

exampleSentence: Elle a de la fièvre et doit rester au lit.
exampleTranslation: She has a fever and must stay in bed.
contextNotes: Used with the verb 'avoir': 'avoir de la fièvre' (to have a fever).

exampleSentence: Après une longue journée, il faut se reposer.
exampleTranslation: After a long day, one must rest.
contextNotes: This is a reflexive verb, meaning the subject is performing the action on themselves.

exampleSentence: Elle a cassé son bras en tombant.
exampleTranslation: She broke her arm while falling.
contextNotes: One of the essential body parts. Note the silent 's'.

exampleSentence: J'ai marché toute la journée, j'ai mal aux pieds.
exampleTranslation: I walked all day, my feet hurt.
contextNotes: Another essential body part. Plural is 'les pieds'.

exampleSentence: Il a du mal à respirer à cause de son rhume.
exampleTranslation: He has trouble breathing because of his cold.
contextNotes: Used both literally ('respirer l'air') and figuratively ('laisser respirer' - to give space).

exampleSentence: La douleur est insupportable, je dois prendre un antidouleur.
exampleTranslation: The pain is unbearable, I must take a painkiller.
contextNotes: More formal and intense than 'mal'. Used often in medical contexts to describe chronic or severe pain.

exampleSentence: Quels sont les symptômes de cette maladie ?
exampleTranslation: What are the symptoms of this illness?
contextNotes: Used exactly as in English, particularly when describing health issues to a professional.

exampleSentence: Le pharmacien m'a donné les médicaments avec l'ordonnance.
exampleTranslation: The pharmacist gave me the medicine with the prescription.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to the doctor's written instruction for medication. Often shortened to 'une ordo' in informal speech.

exampleSentence: J'espère qu'il va se rétablir rapidement après l'opération.
exampleTranslation: I hope he will recover quickly after the operation.
contextNotes: A formal way to say 'get well'. Less common than 'aller mieux' (to be better), but essential for discussing full recovery.

exampleSentence: La guérison complète de la blessure a pris plusieurs mois.
exampleTranslation: The complete healing of the injury took several months.
contextNotes: Related to the verb 'guérir' (to heal). This noun is used when discussing the process or state of being healed, often in serious contexts.

exampleSentence: Pour une bonne santé, il faut adopter une hygiène de vie équilibrée.
exampleTranslation: For good health, one must adopt balanced lifestyle habits.
contextNotes: A comprehensive term covering diet, sleep, exercise, and stress management. Used frequently in public health discourse.

exampleSentence: J'ai besoin d'une nouvelle chemise blanche pour le travail.
exampleTranslation: I need a new white shirt for work.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to a collared, button-down shirt (dress shirt or casual shirt). A T-shirt is 'un tee-shirt'.

exampleSentence: Ce pantalon est trop serré à la taille.
exampleTranslation: These trousers are too tight at the waist.
contextNotes: Always singular in French ('le pantalon') even though it refers to two legs. Plural 'les pantalons' is used when referring to multiple pairs.

exampleSentence: Elle a acheté une belle robe rouge pour la fête.
exampleTranslation: She bought a beautiful red dress for the party.
contextNotes: Used for any type of dress. Be careful not to confuse it with 'la robe de chambre' (dressing gown).

exampleSentence: Où sont mes chaussures de sport ?
exampleTranslation: Where are my sports shoes?
contextNotes: Always used in the plural. Specific types include 'les baskets' (sneakers) or 'les bottes' (boots).

exampleSentence: Il fait froid, mets ton manteau !
exampleTranslation: It's cold, put on your coat!
contextNotes: A general term for a heavy outer garment. 'La veste' is usually shorter (a jacket or blazer).

exampleSentence: J'ai oublié mon sac à main dans la voiture.
exampleTranslation: I forgot my handbag in the car.
contextNotes: A versatile word. 'Un sac à main' is a handbag/purse; 'un sac à dos' is a backpack.

exampleSentence: Il porte toujours un chapeau en été pour se protéger du soleil.
exampleTranslation: He always wears a hat in summer to protect himself from the sun.
contextNotes: General term for a hat. 'Le bonnet' refers specifically to a knitted cap or beanie.

exampleSentence: Quelle est votre taille de pantalon ?
exampleTranslation: What is your pant size?
contextNotes: Used for clothing sizes (e.g., S, M, L). For shoe size, use 'la pointure'.

exampleSentence: J'ai perdu une de mes chaussettes dans la machine à laver.
exampleTranslation: I lost one of my socks in the washing machine.
contextNotes: Always plural. Essential vocabulary for laundry or shopping.

exampleSentence: J'ai laissé mon portefeuille sur la table du café.
exampleTranslation: I left my wallet on the café table.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to a men's wallet. A woman's large wallet/clutch is often 'un porte-monnaie' or 'une pochette'.

exampleSentence: J'ai mis un gilet en laine pour avoir plus chaud.
exampleTranslation: I put on a wool cardigan to be warmer.
contextNotes: This word is ambiguous: it can mean a cardigan (knitted), a waistcoat (suit vest), or a high-visibility safety vest ('gilet jaune'). Context is key.

exampleSentence: Elle a noué l'écharpe autour de son cou avec élégance.
exampleTranslation: She tied the scarf around her neck elegantly.
contextNotes: Used for winter scarves or fashion scarves. Note the liaison: 'l'écharpe'.

exampleSentence: N'oublie pas ton maillot de bain si tu vas à la piscine.
exampleTranslation: Don't forget your swimsuit if you go to the pool.
contextNotes: Literally 'bathing jersey'. For men, often shortened to 'un maillot' or 'un short de bain'. For a bikini, use 'un bikini'.

exampleSentence: La doublure en soie rend ce blouson très confortable.
exampleTranslation: The silk lining makes this jacket very comfortable.
contextNotes: A technical term often used when describing the quality or material composition of clothing, indicating a higher level of vocabulary.

translation: To look sharp / to cut a dash
exampleSentence: Avec son nouveau costume, il a vraiment fière allure.
exampleTranslation: In his new suit, he really looks sharp.
contextNotes: An idiomatic phrase used to compliment someone's appearance, especially when they are well-dressed or stylish. It implies confidence and elegance.

exampleSentence: J'ai besoin d'argent pour acheter du pain.
exampleTranslation: I need money to buy bread.
contextNotes: The word 'argent' literally means silver, but is the standard term for money. It is masculine.

exampleSentence: Je vais payer par carte s'il vous plaît.
exampleTranslation: I will pay by card, please.
contextNotes: A regular -ER verb. When paying in a shop, 'Je vais payer' or 'Je peux payer' are common phrases.

exampleSentence: Quel est le prix de cette veste ?
exampleTranslation: What is the price of this jacket?
contextNotes: Used exactly like the English 'price'. Not to be confused with 'le prix' (the prize/award).

exampleSentence: Il y a beaucoup de monde à la caisse.
exampleTranslation: There are a lot of people at the checkout.
contextNotes: Refers to the physical location where you pay (the register or the counter). Often seen as 'Passage à la caisse'.

exampleSentence: Gardez bien votre reçu en cas d'échange.
exampleTranslation: Keep your receipt carefully in case of an exchange.
contextNotes: Also sometimes referred to as 'le ticket de caisse', especially for smaller purchases.

exampleSentence: Nous allons acheter des légumes au marché.
exampleTranslation: We are going to buy vegetables at the market.
contextNotes: A very common -ER verb. Note the change in the accent when conjugated (e.g., J'achète).

exampleSentence: Ce magasin vend des produits locaux.
exampleTranslation: This store sells local products.
contextNotes: A regular -RE verb, the opposite of 'acheter'.

exampleSentence: Vous avez de la monnaie pour le bus ?
exampleTranslation: Do you have change for the bus?
contextNotes: Refers specifically to coins or small denominations. Also means 'currency' (e.g., 'la monnaie européenne').

exampleSentence: J'ai eu une réduction de 10% sur ce livre.
exampleTranslation: I got a 10% discount on this book.
contextNotes: Often used interchangeably with 'une remise' or 'une promotion' when referring to sales.

exampleSentence: Où se trouve le distributeur le plus proche ?
exampleTranslation: Where is the nearest ATM?
contextNotes: Short for 'distributeur automatique de billets' (DAB). This is the standard, shortened term used in conversation.

exampleSentence: L'inflation affecte directement le pouvoir d'achat des ménages.
exampleTranslation: Inflation directly affects the purchasing power of households.
contextNotes: A key term in economic discussions, often heard in news reports regarding consumer spending and wages.

translation: to window shop (lit. to lick the window)
exampleSentence: Nous avons passé l'après-midi à faire du lèche-vitrine.
exampleTranslation: We spent the afternoon window shopping.
contextNotes: A colorful and common French idiom. 'Vitrine' means shop window.

exampleSentence: Mon solde bancaire est très bas ce mois-ci.
exampleTranslation: My bank balance is very low this month.
contextNotes: Context dependent. 'Les soldes' (plural) refers to the official, seasonal sales periods in France, which are heavily regulated.

exampleSentence: L'achat de produits de contrefaçon est illégal en France.
exampleTranslation: The purchase of counterfeit products is illegal in France.
contextNotes: A serious term, especially relevant in France due to the luxury goods industry. Often used in legal or official contexts.

exampleSentence: La trésorerie de l'entreprise est saine malgré la crise.
exampleTranslation: The company's cash flow is healthy despite the crisis.
contextNotes: Refers to the management of liquid assets, typically used in a business or governmental financial context.

exampleSentence: Mon enfant va à l'école primaire tous les jours.
exampleTranslation: My child goes to primary school every day.
contextNotes: In France, 'l'école' usually refers to primary or secondary school. University is usually 'l'université' or 'la faculté'.

exampleSentence: Le professeur a donné beaucoup de devoirs.
exampleTranslation: The teacher gave a lot of homework.
contextNotes: Often shortened to 'le prof' (informal). 'La professeure' is the feminine form, though 'le professeur' is sometimes used for women, especially at higher levels.

exampleSentence: Je dois étudier pour l'examen d'histoire demain.
exampleTranslation: I must study for the history exam tomorrow.
contextNotes: A regular -ER verb. Used broadly for academic study, preparation, or research.

exampleSentence: Où est mon livre de mathématiques ?
exampleTranslation: Where is my mathematics book?
contextNotes: Essential classroom vocabulary. Note the liaison in 'les livres' (lay-leevr).

exampleSentence: J'ai fini tous mes devoirs avant le dîner.
exampleTranslation: I finished all my homework before dinner.
contextNotes: Always plural in French, meaning 'duties' or 'assignments.' The verb used is usually 'faire' (faire les devoirs).

exampleSentence: Nous avons cours dans la classe 305.
exampleTranslation: We have class in classroom 305.
contextNotes: Can refer both to the physical room ('classroom') and the group of students or the lesson itself ('class').

exampleSentence: Elle a réussi son examen de conduite du premier coup.
exampleTranslation: She passed her driving test on the first try.
contextNotes: A regular -IR verb. Very common for academic achievement. The opposite is 'échouer' (to fail).

exampleSentence: Quand est-ce que nous aurons les résultats de l'examen ?
exampleTranslation: When will we get the exam results?
contextNotes: Often shortened to 'l'épreuve' (the test/trial) or 'le contrôle' (a short quiz/assessment).

exampleSentence: J'apprends le français depuis deux ans.
exampleTranslation: I have been learning French for two years.
contextNotes: Irregular verb. Also means 'to teach' when followed by an indirect object (e.g., 'apprendre quelque chose à quelqu'un').

exampleSentence: Quelle est ta matière préférée au lycée ?
exampleTranslation: What is your favorite subject in high school?
contextNotes: Can also mean 'material' or 'substance.' In an educational context, it refers to disciplines like history, science, or literature.

exampleSentence: Les parents reçoivent le bulletin scolaire à la fin de chaque trimestre.
exampleTranslation: Parents receive the school report card at the end of each trimester.
contextNotes: Short for 'le bulletin scolaire.' This document details the student's grades and teacher comments.

exampleSentence: Ce cursus universitaire dure cinq ans et inclut un stage obligatoire.
exampleTranslation: This university course of study lasts five years and includes a mandatory internship.
contextNotes: Refers to the overall sequence of studies or the academic path taken, especially in higher education.

exampleSentence: L'école utilise une pédagogie très axée sur l'apprentissage par projet.
exampleTranslation: The school uses a teaching method heavily focused on project-based learning.
contextNotes: Refers to the theory and practice of education and teaching. Often discussed in teacher training programs.

exampleSentence: Son assiduité aux cours et son travail constant lui ont permis d'obtenir la meilleure note.
exampleTranslation: Her diligence in classes and constant work allowed her to get the best grade.
contextNotes: A formal term often used in official reports or academic evaluations to praise a student’s consistent effort and presence.

exampleSentence: Après deux ans d'essai, le jeune enseignant a obtenu sa titularisation.
exampleTranslation: After two years of probation, the young teacher obtained his permanent appointment (tenure).
contextNotes: Specific to the French public sector education system, referring to the formal process of becoming a permanent, civil servant teacher ('fonctionnaire'), which grants job security.

exampleSentence: J'aime mon travail, il est très intéressant.
exampleTranslation: I like my job, it is very interesting.
contextNotes: This is the general term for 'work' or 'a job/employment'. If you mean the physical workplace, you might use 'le bureau'.

exampleSentence: Elle cherche un nouvel emploi dans le secteur de la finance.
exampleTranslation: She is looking for a new job in the finance sector.
contextNotes: Often used specifically when discussing employment status or job searching (e.g., 'offre d'emploi' - job offer).

exampleSentence: Le salaire minimum a augmenté cette année.
exampleTranslation: The minimum wage increased this year.
contextNotes: Refers to the fixed payment made to an employee, usually monthly in France. 'La paie' is a more casual term for 'paycheck'.

exampleSentence: Nous travaillons de 9h à 17h tous les jours.
exampleTranslation: We work from 9 am to 5 pm every day.
contextNotes: A regular -ER verb. Essential for discussing daily routine and professional life.

exampleSentence: J'ai déjeuné avec un collègue hier midi.
exampleTranslation: I had lunch with a colleague yesterday at noon.
contextNotes: The feminine form is 'une collègue'. Used frequently in professional settings.

exampleSentence: Notre patronne est en réunion toute la matinée.
exampleTranslation: Our boss (f) is in a meeting all morning.
contextNotes: While 'le directeur' (director) is more formal, 'le patron' is the common term for the immediate superior or business owner.

exampleSentence: J'ai un entretien d'embauche la semaine prochaine.
exampleTranslation: I have a job interview next week.
contextNotes: Always specify 'entretien d'embauche' (hiring interview) to avoid confusion with maintenance ('entretien').

exampleSentence: Le taux de chômage a légèrement baissé ce trimestre.
exampleTranslation: The unemployment rate slightly decreased this quarter.
contextNotes: A very common topic in French economic and political discussions. Someone who is unemployed is 'un chômeur' (m) or 'une chômeuse' (f).

exampleSentence: Elle a fait une longue carrière dans l'enseignement.
exampleTranslation: She had a long career in teaching.
contextNotes: Refers to the progression and sequence of professional roles throughout one's life.

exampleSentence: L'entreprise a dû licencier une partie du personnel.
exampleTranslation: The company had to lay off some of the staff.
contextNotes: This verb implies termination by the employer. The noun is 'le licenciement'. Note that 'virer' is a more informal term for firing someone.

exampleSentence: Nous devons suivre une formation obligatoire sur les nouvelles normes de sécurité.
exampleTranslation: We must follow mandatory training on the new safety standards.
contextNotes: Refers both to professional training (continuing education) and academic education. 'Formation professionnelle' is a key concept in French labor law.

exampleSentence: Après dix ans, il a décidé de démissionner pour créer sa propre affaire.
exampleTranslation: After ten years, he decided to resign to start his own business.
contextNotes: This verb is used when the employee chooses to leave their position voluntarily. The noun is 'la démission'.

exampleSentence: Les avantages sociaux comprennent l'assurance maladie et la retraite.
exampleTranslation: The employee benefits include health insurance and retirement.
contextNotes: A crucial phrase when discussing job offers and compensation packages in France, where social security contributions are mandatory.

exampleSentence: Beaucoup d'entreprises ont adopté le télétravail depuis la pandémie.
exampleTranslation: Many companies have adopted remote work since the pandemic.
contextNotes: This term has become extremely common and standardized in French professional language, replacing less formal phrases like 'travailler à distance'.

exampleSentence: Pour moi, l'épanouissement professionnel est plus important que le simple gain financier.
exampleTranslation: For me, professional fulfillment is more important than simple financial gain.
contextNotes: This abstract noun is used in high-level discussions about career satisfaction, well-being, and personal growth within a job role.

exampleSentence: La boulangerie se trouve au coin de la rue.
exampleTranslation: The bakery is located on the corner of the street.
contextNotes: A fundamental word for urban navigation. Often used in addresses (e.g., 10, rue Victor Hugo).

exampleSentence: Paris est une très grande ville.
exampleTranslation: Paris is a very large city.
contextNotes: Used for both large cities and smaller towns. The equivalent of 'countryside' is 'la campagne'.

exampleSentence: J'habite dans un quartier très calme.
exampleTranslation: I live in a very quiet neighborhood.
contextNotes: Refers to a specific administrative or cultural section of a city. In Paris, the 'quartiers' are smaller divisions within the 20 'arrondissements'.

exampleSentence: Nous devons aller à l'aéroport deux heures avant le vol.
exampleTranslation: We must go to the airport two hours before the flight.
contextNotes: Always masculine, even though it starts with a vowel (l'aéroport). The 's' is silent.

exampleSentence: Où est la gare centrale, s'il vous plaît ?
exampleTranslation: Where is the central train station, please?
contextNotes: Crucial for travel in France, as train travel (TGV) is very common. The metro station is 'la station de métro'.

exampleSentence: Nous avons pris un chemin plus court à travers les bois.
exampleTranslation: We took a shorter path through the woods.
contextNotes: Can mean a physical path or a figurative way/route. Often combined, like 'chemin de fer' (railway).

exampleSentence: Le paysage des Alpes est magnifique en hiver.
exampleTranslation: The landscape of the Alps is magnificent in winter.
contextNotes: Refers to the view or the natural environment. Used frequently when discussing travel or nature photography.

exampleSentence: Nous avons traversé la frontière entre la France et l'Espagne.
exampleTranslation: We crossed the border between France and Spain.
contextNotes: Important term in Europe, especially since many EU countries share open borders.

exampleSentence: Y a-t-il de bons restaurants dans les environs ?
exampleTranslation: Are there good restaurants in the vicinity?
contextNotes: Always used in the plural. A very common way to ask about nearby places or amenities.

exampleSentence: Nous avons planifié l'itinéraire de notre voyage en Provence.
exampleTranslation: We planned the itinerary for our trip to Provence.
contextNotes: More formal than 'le chemin' or 'la route'. Refers to a detailed plan of a journey or a specific mapped route.

exampleSentence: Ce petit village médiéval est vraiment pittoresque.
exampleTranslation: This small medieval village is truly picturesque.
contextNotes: A common adjective used in travel writing and descriptions of charming, old-fashioned places, especially villages or small towns.

translation: the layout / the development / the planning
exampleSentence: L'aménagement du nouveau parc a pris deux ans.
exampleTranslation: The development (or planning/layout) of the new park took two years.
contextNotes: Refers to the organization, planning, or arrangement of a space, often used in urban planning ('l'aménagement urbain').

exampleSentence: Les petites ruelles forment un véritable dédale dans la vieille ville.
exampleTranslation: The small alleys form a veritable maze in the old town.
contextNotes: Used literally for a maze, but often figuratively to describe a complicated network of streets or corridors.

exampleSentence: Cette petite région est une enclave culturelle au milieu du pays.
exampleTranslation: This small region is a cultural enclave in the middle of the country.
contextNotes: A geographical or political term referring to a territory completely surrounded by another territory, or used metaphorically for a distinct cultural area.

exampleSentence: L'accès à l'héliport est strictement réservé au personnel autorisé.
exampleTranslation: Access to the heliport is strictly reserved for authorized personnel.
contextNotes: A specialized term for a helicopter landing area, generally only encountered in specific professional or high-end contexts.

exampleSentence: J'ai acheté mon billet de train en ligne.
exampleTranslation: I bought my train ticket online.
contextNotes: Used for all types of tickets (train, plane, museum, concert). 'Billet d'avion' (plane ticket), 'billet aller-retour' (round-trip ticket).

exampleSentence: Nous aimons voyager en Europe chaque été.
exampleTranslation: We like to travel in Europe every summer.
contextNotes: The most common verb for general travel. The noun is 'le voyage' (the trip).

exampleSentence: La gare est très animée ce matin.
exampleTranslation: The train station is very busy this morning.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to the train station. For the bus station, use 'la gare routière' or 'la station de bus'.

exampleSentence: Mon vol part de l'aéroport Charles de Gaulle.
exampleTranslation: My flight leaves from Charles de Gaulle airport.
contextNotes: A compound noun, always masculine. Remember the liaison with the article 'l'': 'l'aéroport'.

exampleSentence: Où est ma valise bleue ?
exampleTranslation: Where is my blue suitcase?
contextNotes: Refers to standard luggage. For carry-on luggage, you might hear 'le bagage à main'.

exampleSentence: Je vais prendre le métro pour aller au travail.
exampleTranslation: I am going to take the subway to go to work.
contextNotes: Essential verb used when discussing using public transport: 'prendre le bus', 'prendre un taxi', 'prendre l'avion'.

exampleSentence: Nous devons passer par la douane avant de récupérer nos bagages.
exampleTranslation: We must go through customs before collecting our luggage.
contextNotes: Refers to the government agency responsible for monitoring goods and people entering a country. Often used with the verb 'passer par' (to go through).

exampleSentence: Le train pour Lyon partira du quai numéro 3.
exampleTranslation: The train for Lyon will depart from platform number 3.
contextNotes: Used for train platforms (especially in stations like the SNCF) and also for docks or piers where boats load/unload.

exampleSentence: Avez-vous vérifié l'itinéraire sur la carte ?
exampleTranslation: Did you check the route on the map?
contextNotes: Refers to the planned route or schedule of a trip. Often used when planning road trips or complex travel schedules.

exampleSentence: J'ai une correspondance de deux heures à Francfort.
exampleTranslation: I have a two-hour connection in Frankfurt.
contextNotes: Crucial term for public transportation, especially flights and trains, meaning the required transfer between two legs of a journey.

exampleSentence: Après mon vol transatlantique, je souffre d'un terrible décalage horaire.
exampleTranslation: After my transatlantic flight, I am suffering from terrible jet lag.
contextNotes: A specific term used to describe the physiological effect of traveling across time zones (jet lag). Can also simply mean 'time difference'.

exampleSentence: N'oubliez pas d'emporter votre passeport.
exampleTranslation: Don't forget to bring your passport.
contextNotes: Basic travel document. In French, the 't' at the end is usually silent.

exampleSentence: Nous devons réserver une chambre d'hôtel pour la semaine prochaine.
exampleTranslation: We must book a hotel room for next week.
contextNotes: Used for booking hotels, flights, tables at restaurants, etc. The noun is 'la réservation'.

exampleSentence: Il y a beaucoup de péages sur l'autoroute du Sud.
exampleTranslation: There are many tolls on the Southern highway.
contextNotes: Essential vocabulary for driving in France, as many major highways ('autoroutes') require payment at toll booths ('barrières de péage').

exampleSentence: L'heure d'embarquement est à 14h30.
exampleTranslation: The boarding time is at 2:30 PM.
contextNotes: Used primarily for planes and ships. The verb is 'embarquer' (to board). Look for 'Porte d'embarquement' (Boarding Gate) at the airport.

exampleSentence: Le soleil brille aujourd'hui, c'est une belle journée.
exampleTranslation: The sun is shining today, it's a beautiful day.
contextNotes: A fundamental word. Used frequently in common weather expressions like 'Il fait soleil' (It is sunny).

exampleSentence: N'oublie pas ton parapluie, il va y avoir de la pluie.
exampleTranslation: Don't forget your umbrella, there is going to be rain.
contextNotes: Often used with the impersonal verb 'pleuvoir' (to rain). 'Il pleut' means 'It is raining'.

exampleSentence: Le vent est très fort près de la côte.
exampleTranslation: The wind is very strong near the coast.
contextNotes: To express that it is windy, the common phrase is 'Il y a du vent' or 'Il fait du vent'.

exampleSentence: Nous allons faire de la randonnée dans la montagne cet été.
exampleTranslation: We are going hiking in the mountain this summer.
contextNotes: France has several major mountain ranges (Alpes, Pyrénées, Massif Central), making this a very common geographical term.

exampleSentence: Il y a un grand arbre dans le jardin public.
exampleTranslation: There is a large tree in the public garden.
contextNotes: Takes the definite article 'l'' because it starts with a vowel. Remember the gender is masculine.

exampleSentence: J'aime nager dans la mer quand il fait chaud.
exampleTranslation: I like to swim in the sea when it is hot.
contextNotes: Distinguished from 'l'océan' (the ocean). Used in the common phrase 'au bord de la mer' (by the seaside).

exampleSentence: Il fait très froid ce matin, mets ton manteau.
exampleTranslation: It is very cold this morning, put on your coat.
contextNotes: When describing the weather, use the impersonal expression 'Il fait froid'. When describing an object or person, use 'être' (e.g., 'Je suis froid').

exampleSentence: Attention, le café est trop chaud.
exampleTranslation: Be careful, the coffee is too hot.
contextNotes: Similar usage note to 'froid'. For weather, use 'Il fait chaud'. For objects/people, use 'être'.

exampleSentence: Quelle est ta saison préférée : l'hiver ou l'été ?
exampleTranslation: What is your favorite season: winter or summer?
contextNotes: Refers to the four seasons (printemps, été, automne, hiver). Essential for discussing climate cycles.

exampleSentence: Le brouillard était si épais que nous ne pouvions pas voir la route.
exampleTranslation: The fog was so thick that we couldn't see the road.
contextNotes: Used in weather reports. To say it's foggy, use 'Il y a du brouillard'.

exampleSentence: Un violent orage a éclaté hier soir, avec beaucoup d'éclairs.
exampleTranslation: A violent thunderstorm broke out last night, with lots of lightning.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to a storm involving thunder and lightning. Takes the definite article 'l''.

exampleSentence: Nous souffrons de la canicule depuis plus d'une semaine.
exampleTranslation: We have been suffering from the heatwave for over a week.
contextNotes: This term has become increasingly common in French media due to rising summer temperatures in Europe.

exampleSentence: La protection du littoral contre l'érosion est une priorité écologique.
exampleTranslation: Protecting the coastline against erosion is an ecological priority.
contextNotes: A more formal or geographical term than 'la plage' (the beach) or 'le bord de mer'.

exampleSentence: Le dégel printanier provoque souvent des inondations dans la région.
exampleTranslation: The spring thaw often causes floods in the region.
contextNotes: Derived from the verb 'dégeler' (to thaw). Used in discussions about climate, agriculture, and hydrology.

exampleSentence: La préservation de cet écosystème fragile est cruciale pour la biodiversité.
exampleTranslation: The preservation of this fragile ecosystem is crucial for biodiversity.
contextNotes: A scientific and environmental term. Often used in formal discussions about nature and conservation efforts.

exampleSentence: Mon chien adore jouer au parc tous les jours.
exampleTranslation: My dog loves to play at the park every day.
contextNotes: One of the most common pets. 'Chien' is masculine. The feminine form is 'chienne', but 'le chien' is often used generically.

exampleSentence: Le chat dort sur le canapé toute la journée.
exampleTranslation: The cat sleeps on the sofa all day long.
contextNotes: Another very common pet. 'Chat' is masculine. The feminine form is 'chatte', but be careful as this can sometimes be vulgar slang.

exampleSentence: Nous avons acheté un nouveau poisson rouge pour l'aquarium.
exampleTranslation: We bought a new goldfish for the aquarium.
contextNotes: Literally 'red fish'. The word 'poisson' (fish) is masculine.

exampleSentence: Il faut nettoyer la cage du hamster ce soir.
exampleTranslation: We must clean the hamster's cage tonight.
contextNotes: Used for birds, rodents, and sometimes transportation of smaller animals. Always feminine.

exampleSentence: N'oubliez pas de nourrir les lapins avant de partir.
exampleTranslation: Don't forget to feed the rabbits before leaving.
contextNotes: A regular -IR verb. Essential for discussing pet care routines.

exampleSentence: Mets la laisse à ton chien avant de sortir dans la rue.
exampleTranslation: Put the leash on your dog before going out into the street.
contextNotes: Required by law in many French cities for walking dogs in public areas.

exampleSentence: J'ai pris rendez-vous chez le véto pour une vaccination.
exampleTranslation: I made an appointment at the vet for a vaccination.
contextNotes: The full word is 'vétérinaire', but 'véto' is the extremely common, informal abbreviation used daily in France.

exampleSentence: Elle aime jouer avec sa balle dans le jardin.
exampleTranslation: She likes to play with her ball in the garden.
contextNotes: A regular -ER verb. When talking about playing with an object, use 'jouer avec' (to play with).

exampleSentence: Quelles croquettes donnez-vous à votre labrador ?
exampleTranslation: What kibble do you give your Labrador?
contextNotes: Always used in the plural when referring to dry pet food (dog or cat). A very practical word for pet owners.

exampleSentence: Il faut changer la litière du chat tous les trois jours.
exampleTranslation: The cat litter needs to be changed every three days.
contextNotes: Refers both to the box itself and the material inside. Essential vocabulary for cat owners.

exampleSentence: Nous laissons notre chien au chenil pendant nos vacances.
exampleTranslation: We leave our dog at the kennel during our vacation.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to a commercial boarding facility or dog shelter, not usually a small doghouse (which is 'la niche').

exampleSentence: Il est important de caresser les animaux pour les rassurer.
exampleTranslation: It is important to pet animals to reassure them.
contextNotes: A regular -ER verb. Used specifically for the act of gently stroking an animal or person.

exampleSentence: Nous avons décidé d'adopter un chat à la SPA.
exampleTranslation: We decided to adopt a cat from the SPA (animal protection society).
contextNotes: Used when taking an animal from a shelter or rescue group. SPA stands for 'Société Protectrice des Animaux'.

exampleSentence: Le toilettage régulier est crucial pour les chiens à poils longs.
exampleTranslation: Regular grooming is crucial for long-haired dogs.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to professional pet grooming (washing, cutting hair, trimming nails). Related to the verb 'se toiletter' (to groom oneself).

exampleSentence: La stérilisation aide à contrôler la population des animaux errants.
exampleTranslation: Sterilization helps control the stray animal population.
contextNotes: A formal term used in veterinary and animal welfare contexts. Essential for discussing responsible pet ownership.

exampleSentence: Quel est ton sport préféré ?
exampleTranslation: What is your favorite sport?
contextNotes: Used broadly to refer to physical activity or competitive sports. Often used in the singular, even when referring to sports in general.

exampleSentence: Nous aimons jouer au football le week-end.
exampleTranslation: We like to play soccer on the weekend.
contextNotes: When playing a sport, use 'jouer à' (e.g., jouer au tennis). When playing an instrument, use 'jouer de' (e.g., jouer du piano).

exampleSentence: La lecture est un excellent passe-temps relaxant.
exampleTranslation: Reading is an excellent relaxing hobby.
contextNotes: Refers to the act of reading as a hobby or activity. The verb is 'lire' (to read).

exampleSentence: Je fais du vélo tous les matins.
exampleTranslation: I cycle every morning (literally: I do bike every morning).
contextNotes: To express the activity of cycling, use the construction 'faire du vélo'.

exampleSentence: Elle passe des heures à dessiner des paysages.
exampleTranslation: She spends hours drawing landscapes.
contextNotes: A common hobby verb. Do not confuse with 'designer' (to design).

exampleSentence: Notre équipe de basket a gagné le match.
exampleTranslation: Our basketball team won the game.
contextNotes: Although it ends in 'e', it is feminine ('une équipe'). Essential word for team sports.

exampleSentence: J'adore la natation pendant l'été.
exampleTranslation: I love swimming during the summer.
contextNotes: Refers to the sport/activity. The verb is 'nager' (to swim).

exampleSentence: L'entraînement commence à six heures.
exampleTranslation: The training session starts at six o'clock.
contextNotes: The verb 's'entraîner' means 'to train oneself' or 'to practice'.

exampleSentence: Nous avons fait une longue randonnée dans les Alpes.
exampleTranslation: We went on a long hike in the Alps.
contextNotes: A very popular activity in France. Often paired with the verb 'faire' (faire de la randonnée).

exampleSentence: Mon père passe ses samedis à faire du bricolage dans le garage.
exampleTranslation: My father spends his Saturdays doing DIY in the garage.
contextNotes: A quintessential French hobby, referring to home improvement, repairs, or crafting. The verb is 'bricoler'.

exampleSentence: Il a appris la voile sur la côte bretonne.
exampleTranslation: He learned sailing on the Brittany coast.
contextNotes: Literally means 'the sail'. Used to refer to the activity of sailing, especially competitive or recreational boating.

exampleSentence: J'ai pris un abonnement à la salle de sport.
exampleTranslation: I took out a membership at the gym.
contextNotes: Crucial vocabulary for joining clubs, gyms, or subscribing to hobby-related magazines/services.

exampleSentence: Courir un marathon demande beaucoup d'endurance.
exampleTranslation: Running a marathon requires a lot of stamina.
contextNotes: Key term in fitness and competitive sports contexts. Related adjective is 'endurant' (enduring).

translation: to exceed one's limits / to surpass oneself
exampleSentence: Pour atteindre ce niveau, il faut apprendre à se surpasser.
exampleTranslation: To reach this level, one must learn to exceed one's limits.
contextNotes: Used in motivational or high-level contexts, describing the mental and physical effort required to overcome personal boundaries in sports or hobbies.

exampleSentence: Ce type d'artisanat exige une grande dextérité manuelle.
exampleTranslation: This type of craft requires great manual dexterity.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to skill and precision, often used when discussing fine arts, complex crafts, or highly technical sports (like fencing or archery).

exampleSentence: J'ai oublié mon téléphone portable à la maison.
exampleTranslation: I forgot my mobile phone at home.
contextNotes: In French, 'téléphone portable' (or 'portable') is the common term for a mobile/cell phone, while 'téléphone fixe' refers to a landline.

exampleSentence: Mon nouvel ordinateur est très rapide.
exampleTranslation: My new computer is very fast.
contextNotes: The term 'PC' (pronounced 'pay-say') is also commonly used, especially for personal computers.

exampleSentence: Nous avons besoin d'internet pour travailler à distance.
exampleTranslation: We need the internet to work remotely.
contextNotes: Unlike English, where 'the internet' is common, French often uses just 'internet' without the article 'l' (though 'sur internet' is common for 'on the internet').

exampleSentence: Je t'ai envoyé un message hier soir.
exampleTranslation: I sent you a message last night.
contextNotes: This word covers both traditional messages and text messages (SMS). For texting, 'texto' is also frequently used informally.

exampleSentence: Veuillez m'envoyer les documents par email.
exampleTranslation: Please send me the documents by email.
contextNotes: While 'email' is widely understood and used, the official French term recommended by language bodies is 'courriel'.

exampleSentence: Le clavier de mon ordinateur portable est sale.
exampleTranslation: The keyboard of my laptop is dirty.
contextNotes: Refers to both computer keyboards and musical keyboards. Be careful not to confuse it with 'souris' (mouse).

exampleSentence: Elle passe trop de temps sur les réseaux sociaux.
exampleTranslation: She spends too much time on social networks.
contextNotes: Always pluralized as 'réseaux sociaux' when referring to multiple platforms (Facebook, Instagram, etc.).

exampleSentence: Je dois télécharger cette application pour l'utiliser.
exampleTranslation: I must download this application to use it.
contextNotes: The opposite, 'to upload,' is 'téléverser' or sometimes 'mettre en ligne' (to put online).

exampleSentence: Comment puis-je me connecter au Wi-Fi ici?
exampleTranslation: How can I connect to the Wi-Fi here?
contextNotes: Often used reflexively ('se connecter') when talking about logging in or connecting oneself to a network.

exampleSentence: J'ai oublié mon mot de passe et je suis bloqué.
exampleTranslation: I forgot my password and I am locked out.
contextNotes: Literally translates to 'word of passage.' For security, you might hear 'un mot de passe fort' (a strong password).

exampleSentence: L'interface utilisateur de ce logiciel est très intuitive.
exampleTranslation: The user interface of this software is very intuitive.
contextNotes: A direct borrowing, but always feminine ('une interface'). Refers to the point of interaction between a user and a machine/program.

exampleSentence: La transition vers l'ère numérique a changé nos vies.
exampleTranslation: The transition to the digital era has changed our lives.
contextNotes: Used broadly to describe anything related to digital technology, e.g., 'une photo numérique' (a digital photo).

exampleSentence: Nous avons besoin de plus de bande passante pour la vidéoconférence.
exampleTranslation: We need more bandwidth for the video conference.
contextNotes: A specific technical term essential in discussions about network speed and capacity.

exampleSentence: Le cryptage des données est essentiel pour garantir la confidentialité.
exampleTranslation: Data encryption is essential to guarantee confidentiality.
contextNotes: Used in cybersecurity and advanced technical discussions. The verb is 'crypter'.

exampleSentence: L'obsolescence programmée est une pratique controversée dans l'industrie technologique.
exampleTranslation: Planned obsolescence is a controversial practice in the technology industry.
contextNotes: This term is frequently used in French socio-economic and environmental debates regarding consumer electronics and sustainability.

exampleSentence: La joie de vivre est très importante pour le bien-être.
exampleTranslation: The joy of living is very important for well-being.
contextNotes: Often used in the fixed expression 'la joie de vivre' (the joy of life/living).

exampleSentence: Il est triste parce qu'il a perdu son match.
exampleTranslation: He is sad because he lost his match.
contextNotes: This adjective is invariant in the masculine and feminine singular forms (e.g., 'un homme triste', 'une femme triste').

exampleSentence: Elle a du mal à contrôler sa colère.
exampleTranslation: She has trouble controlling her anger.
contextNotes: To express being angry, use the verb 'être en colère' (to be in anger).

exampleSentence: J'ai peur des araignées et des hauteurs.
exampleTranslation: I am afraid of spiders and heights.
contextNotes: Unlike English, French uses the verb 'avoir' (to have) with 'peur' (fear) to express this emotion.

exampleSentence: Nous sommes très heureux de vous accueillir chez nous.
exampleTranslation: We are very happy to welcome you to our home.
contextNotes: Must agree in gender: 'heureux' (masculine singular/plural) and 'heureuse' (feminine singular), 'heureuses' (feminine plural).

exampleSentence: L'amour est le sentiment le plus fort.
exampleTranslation: Love is the strongest feeling.
contextNotes: Can refer to romantic love or deep affection. Note the contraction 'L'amour' (le amour).

exampleSentence: J'ai beaucoup de stress à cause de mon examen.
exampleTranslation: I have a lot of stress because of my exam.
contextNotes: A common word borrowed from English, used frequently in modern French conversation.

exampleSentence: Après la méditation, je me sens très calme.
exampleTranslation: After meditation, I feel very calm.
contextNotes: Like 'triste', this adjective is invariant in the singular form (masculine and feminine).

exampleSentence: Ne t'inquiète pas, tout ira bien.
exampleTranslation: Don't worry, everything will be fine.
contextNotes: This is a reflexive verb, meaning the action reflects back on the subject. The imperative form 'Ne t'inquiète pas' is extremely common.

exampleSentence: Pour combattre l'ennui, j'ai commencé à lire des romans.
